qas.question: In the 1990's, what is something Houston did to try not to diversify it's economy?

context: One wave of the population boom ended abruptly in the mid-1980s, as <a4_0>oil prices fell<a4_0/> precipitously. The space industry also suffered in <a0_0><b9_0>1986<b9_0/><a0_0/> after the <a5_0>Space Shuttle Challenger<a5_0/> disintegrated shortly after launch. There was a cutback in some activities for a period. In the <a6_0>late 1980s<a6_0/>, the city's economy suffered from <a1_0>the <b10_0>nationwide recession<b10_0/><a1_0/>. After the early 1990s recession, Houston made efforts to diversify its economy by focusing on <a7_0>aerospace and health care<a7_0/>/biotechnology, and <a2_0><b11_0>reduced its dependence on the petroleum industry<b11_0/><a2_0/>. Since <a3_0>the increase of <b12_0>oil prices in the <a8_0>2000s<b12_0/><a8_0/><a3_0/>, the petroleum industry has again increased its share of the local economy.
